title: Remembering Activism: The Cultural Memory of Protest in Europe
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Remembering Activism: The Cultural Memory of Protest in Europe," seeks to provide a comprehensive examination of the remembering and forgetting of activism in Europe since the late 19th century. Through a multi-faceted approach, the project aims to reveal continuities and changes in protest depiction across different media regimes, demonstrate the role of texts, images, and commemorative practices in conveying memory of protest, and show how memory of protest influences later movements.

The project will focus on three distinct study periods (1871-1914, 1960-1970, 2011-2012) and employ innovative methods such as network visualization to map the reproduction of narratives and references. By exploring mediation, afterlives, and memoryscapes, the project will contribute to a major reorientation in cultural memory research, develop analytic tools to capture the cultural transmission of hope, open up new areas of social movement research, and provide critical literacies to rethink collective memory and identity.

Overall, this project will fill a significant gap in the understanding of activism in Europe and offer valuable insights into the cultural memory of protest. The findings will have implications for a wide range of disciplines and contribute to a deeper understanding of the relationship between memory, identity, and social movements.
